dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, you know, we always talk about companies, uh, trying to retain employees, right? Especially in this market.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, you know, we always talk about companies, uh, trying to retain employees, right? Especially in this market.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, definitely. I mean, it's a huge challenge for, like, every sector right now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, definitely. I mean, it's a huge challenge for, like, every sector right now.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right. And what's interesting is how some of the biggest names – Lowe's, Taco Bell, even Walmart – are tackling it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. And what's interesting is how some of the biggest names - Lowe's, Taco Bell, even Walmart - are tackling it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That's why many of the nation's largest companies, from Lowe's to Taco Bell, have turned to Denver-based Guild Education to help them retain employees through offering pathways to high school and college degrees. ... For example, the nation's largest employer Walmart's Live Better U program covers all tuition costs after financial aid, with the employee contributing only $1 a day.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, they're partnering with this Denver-based company called Guild Education. Their whole thing is helping employees, especially frontline workers, get high school and college degrees.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, they're partnering with this Denver-based company called Guild Education. Their whole thing is helping employees, especially frontline workers, get high school and college degrees.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That's why many of the nation's largest companies, from Lowe's to Taco Bell, have turned to Denver-based Guild Education to help them retain employees through offering pathways to high school and college degrees.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow, that's pretty cool. So it's not just, like, a feel-good initiative, then?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow, that's pretty cool. So it's not just, like, a feel-good initiative, then?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Exactly! Rachel Carlson, the CEO of Guild, she was at the Forbes Women's Summit, and she said it's proven: when companies invest in their frontline staff, they see higher retention, recruitment, and even upskilling.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! Rachel Carlson, the C E O of Guild, she was at the Forbes Women's Summit, and she said it's proven: when companies invest in their frontline staff, they see higher retention, recruitment, and even upskilling.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Over the last number of years weve proven that when companies invest in their frontline workforce they become more attractive for people to work at the company and stay at the company [with] higher retention rates, higher recruitment rates, higher up-scaling rates and a more positive brand as a corporate company in America, Guild cofounder and CEO Rachel Carlson said at the Forbes Women's Summit last week.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Huh, so it actually makes them a more attractive place to work. That makes sense, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Huh, so it actually makes them a more attractive place to work. That makes sense, you know?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And it’s not just about, um, white-collar workers. Guild estimates like 64 million frontline and low-income workers need more education to keep up with automation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And it's not just about, um, white-collar workers. Guild estimates like sixty four million frontline and low-income workers need more education to keep up with automation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While many corporate education programs focus on white collar workers, Guild estimates that 64 million frontline and low-income workers will need further education in order to compete in an increasingly automated world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like cashiers, customer service, restaurant staff. That's a massive group. I mean, Walmart's Live Better U program, that's part of this, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like cashiers, customer service, restaurant staff. That's a massive group. I mean, Walmart's Live Better U program, that's part of this, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This group includes cashiers, customer service representatives, restaurant wait staff and cooks, and more. ... For example, the nation's largest employer Walmart's Live Better U program covers all tuition costs after financial aid, with the employee contributing only $1 a day.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yep, exactly. They cover tuition, employees only pay a dollar a day. But, you know, not everyone's totally convinced it's purely altruistic.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yep, exactly. They cover tuition, employees only pay a dollar a day. But, you know, not everyone's totally convinced it's purely altruistic.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, the nation's largest employer Walmart's Live Better U program covers all tuition costs after financial aid, with the employee contributing only $1 a day.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, I can imagine. Like, Stephanie Ruhle from MSNBC, she actually said she's never heard an analyst ask about the 'good' a company is doing on an earnings call.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, I can imagine. Like, Stephanie Ruhle from M S N B C, she actually said she's never heard an analyst ask about the good a company is doing on an earnings call.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When you listen to any analyst call, Ive never heard an analyst ask about the good a company is doing,countered Ruhle.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? But Carlson's counter-point is that CEOs *are* bringing it up in earnings calls because it's boosting profits, recruitment, and retention. It's not just a pat on the back.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? But Carlson's counter-point is that CEOs are bringing it up in earnings calls because it's boosting profits, recruitment, and retention. It's not just a pat on the back.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Carlson says it's because nearly every CEO they work with has mentioned sending their employees back to school as something 'good' in their earnings call. It wasnt them just giving themselves a pat on the back it had lifted their profits, recruitment and retainment, she explained.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, it's actually tied to the bottom line, then. That's, uh, that's really key.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, it's actually tied to the bottom line, then. That's, uh, that's really key.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. And Guild's now even looking at the gig economy, you know, trying to help drivers for companies like Lyft.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. And Guild's now even looking at the gig economy, you know, trying to help drivers for companies like Lyft.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Guild is now looking at how to expand education options to workers in the gig economy. Though Lyft is currently a client offering some educational perks, drivers are not able to receive tuition reimbursement the way other employees might.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, that's interesting. But I bet that's complicated, with, like, the tax implications for those kinds of workers, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, that's interesting. But I bet that's complicated, with, like, the tax implications for those kinds of workers, right?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Totally. The tax code currently doesn't allow for non-taxable education assistance for gig workers, which is, uh, a big hurdle. They're actually lobbying to change it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. The tax code currently doesn't allow for non-taxable education assistance for gig workers, which is, uh, a big hurdle. They're actually lobbying to change it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That's because the tax code doesn't allow companies to provide nontaxable education assistance to those workers. Lobbying to change this tax incentive might be the company's greatest hurdle yet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So, a great idea, but with some serious legislative hoops to jump through. Still, it's a pretty cool way to think about investing in people.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So, a great idea, but with some serious legislative hoops to jump through. Still, it's a pretty cool way to think about investing in people.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, for sure. It's, um, definitely one to watch.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, for sure. It's, um, definitely one to watch.
